title: Rushcliffe Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Peter Shone / Rail Heritage Centre, Rushcliffe Country Park
images.caption: Rail Heritage Centre within the park. This picture is taken from a footbridge over the line, the heritage centre has trains from several eras in varying states of repair.

images.title: Peter Shone / Reed Beds in Rushcliffe Country Park
images.caption: Reed Beds in the park. These reed beds lie at the South Western end of the lake in Rushcliffe Country Park, and provide shelter and nest sites for water fowl. The lake is artificial, the park has been built on a former Royal Ordnance factory site.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / The lake at Rushcliffe Country Park
images.caption: Lake view. The most numerous inhabitants are the Black-headed gulls, but probably the most interesting birds in this view were a pair of courting Shoveler, which can just be distinguished in the higher resolution version.

images.title: Peter Shone / Seedheads in the wildflower meadow
images.caption: Seedheads in the wildflower meadow. This is an early autumn view of the wildflower meadow at the South West corner of the Country Park, in the far left of the picture is Moorend Farm.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Fowemer Hill
images.caption: Fowemer Hill. There was always a slight hill here, which in the period before the war provided a gentle slope for downhill take-offs by a local aviation enthusiast. It was significantly raised in height as part of the development of the Country Park.

images.title: Peter Shone / Golden trees in  a brown autumn meadow
images.caption: Golden trees in a brown autumn meadow. These immature laburnum trees are growing in the wildflower meadow in the country park. This picture is taken from approximately SK 567 320 looking North, the low hill in the background is the highest point in the park's rolling open countryside. The footpaths around the park are popular at lunch time with the workers from the nearby business park.

description: Explore over 200 acres of cycling and walking trails in this popular country park in Ruddington near Nottingham. In the park you will find wildflower meadows, grassland, conservation and landscaped areas. There is also a 2 hectare lake where you can see mute swans, great crested grebes and various duck species. Also look out for skylarks, finches, cuckoos, kestrels, sparrow hawks, reed buntings, reed warblers and sedge warblers.
